modules.description: This module defines a set of token types used to represent parsed elements of a data format, including strings, integers, floats, and structural symbols like braces and commas. It provides functions to parse lines of input into structured rows and headers, handling both complete lines and lines without newlines. The module is used to transform raw text input into typed data structures for further processing.

This module parses structured data rows and headers from input channels or strings, handling errors with detailed location information. It supports both dense and sparse row formats, mapping to lists of values or indexed entries, and converts them into typed values like integers, floats, or strings. Use it to read tabular data with precise error reporting for malformed syntax, unterminated strings, or numeric overflows.

This lexer focuses on parsing tokens from a `Lexing.lexbuf`, handling numeric and string literals, escaped characters, and quoted strings, while offering overflow checks for integers and state transitions. It operates on lexing buffers and files, with functions to tokenize file contents or extract rows for structured text processing. Key use cases include parsing headers and string literals into tokens for downstream parsing, as well as validating and transforming lexed data with robust error handling.

This module defines core data types for representing structured data rows and headers, including dense and sparse formats with optional values. It provides types for numerical and string values, along with row and header structures that distinguish between dense lists and sparse key-value pairs. These types are used to model tabular data with mixed types, supporting operations like row parsing, header alignment, and data serialization.

This module processes structured text data with precise error handling, converting input into typed values like integers, floats, and strings. It supports dense and sparse row formats, working with headers and rows through lexing buffers, input channels, or strings. Use it to parse and validate tabular data, extract tokens, and build typed data structures for further processing or analysis.
